text:
Assorted MATLAB gripes:
- MATLAB's Neural Net Toolbox used to overwrite the activation function with sigmoid, no matter what you passed in. To get that bug fix we would need to pay for the new version of the Toolbox, for everyone.
- Can't mutate arrays in functions. _Sometimes_ the compiler is smart enough to avoid allocation if you pass the array in and assign to it.
- You can have nested functions but you can't use them to mutate any variables they capture. BUT you can always mutate any variables in any part of the call stack using `workspace`.
- Everything about dates pre-2014.
- Every time you call a function in a C library you have to write a MEX function, no shortcuts.
- You want to run two things in parallel? That costs extra!
- Dates as floating point numbers? What could _possibly_ go wrong??
- Mathworks in 2007: no one should ever need to add two 64-bit integers (never mind that C99 had this).
- At least 3 different argument parsing functions, all in proprietary toolboxes and all different.
- Arbitrary conventions around matrix reductions ("vectors" behave different from "matrixes" despite both being matrixes).
- We had used a standard plot function that could plot dates on an axis, when provided as datevecs (Mx3 matrix, with Y,M,D). If you provided exactly 3 datevecs it would assume you were giving it a color map.
- `for` loops iterate over columns because fuck you.
- `length` gives the length of the longest dimension.
- dispatch by file/folder name.

well you just provided a great reason: the slice is arbitrarily defined based on memory layout (MATLAB is column-major, numpy is row-major)

a matrix is not a collection of rows or a collection of columns, that's just how it's implemented
